How to choose the best hair dryer for you
When it comes to buying the best hair dryer for you, there are a number of things to consider.
Power and settings
Primarily, most people want something that will dry their hair quickly and efficiently. On that front, you want to consider windspeed and temperature. For windspeed power, the spec you're looking at here is wattage: higher wattage generally means more power and quicker drying. There's no spec to indicate how hot a hair dryer is going to be, and bear in mind that too much heat will fry your hair, so it's not just a case of the-hotter-the-better, either.
It's also worth factoring in the settings on offer. Most of today's best hair dryers come with three speed options and three temperature options, plus a cool shot to set your style. This gives you a decent amount of control over how you want to dry your hair, and whether you want to prioritize speed or control / hair health.
Weight and size
Another thing to factor in is how comfortable a hair dryer will be to use – and especially if you have longer or thicker hair, and are going to need to be wielding it for a relatively long time. For this, look at weight and size. How the weight is distributed will also play into this; the Supersonics have most of their weight in the handle, which makes them more comfortable to hold than models that weight the same but have heavier barrel sections.
Note that high wattage hair dryers are usually powered by an AC (alternating current) motor, which makes them heavier. Lower wattage hair dryers are more lightweight because they tend to use lighter DC (direct current) motors but they’re not as powerful.
Cord length
Do not underestimate how annoying a short cord can be. Especially worth factoring in if your home's power outlets aren't located near your mirrors.
Tools
Most hair dryers will come with your basic concentrator nozzle, and many also have the option of a diffuser for curly hair. If you have more specific styling needs, some premium options offer more advanced tools. The standout here is Dyson, which has engineered a wide range of tools for different hair types and lengths.
Of course, you don't just need to go for a basic hair dryer – there are plenty of styling tools that also dry hair. If you just want to do bouncy blow-dries, you could opt for a dedicated brush dryer. We're also seeing more options that convert from hair dryer to styler (the Dyson AirWrap and Shark FlexStyle, for example), offering greater flexibility.
Extra features
Back in the day, the most exciting features you could hope for on your hair dryer were a cool shot (to set your style) and ionic technology (for reducing frizz). Now, both of those are very common on the market.
Increasingly, we're starting to see more advanced features geared towards improving hair health. For example, some dryers will have a temperature cycling mode to help lessen heat damage. The Dyson Supersonic Nural has sensors so it knows how close it is to your head, and raises or lowers the heat to maintain a constant temperature on your scalp.
Heating element
If you're worried about hair health, it's worth looking into which heating element your hair dryer comes with. This is the part that warms the air before its projected from the barrel. Dyers with metal elements tend to be more affordable but will cause more heat damage, while ceramic elements distribute heat more evenly, and thus should be gentler on your hair. Finally, tourmaline elements release negative ions in the airflow, which speeds up evaporation of the water molecules reducing drying time and making hair appear smoother.
Once you've chosen your new hair dryer, it may be helpful to check out our guides on how to blow dry your hair the right way and which hair dryer settings you should use to get the results you want without doing any damage.
Frequently asked questions about hair dryers
Which hair dryer brand is best?
Based on our testing, the best hair dryer brands include GHD, T3 and Dyson. GHD is best for reliable, efficient dryers, while T3 has a wider range of offers more innovative features. If you have cash to splash, you should opt for a Dyson. This brand makes consistently excellent hair dryers, which mix efficiency with cutting-edge additions.
What hair dryer is best for curly hair?
Those with curly hair should opt for a hair dryer that includes / has a compatible diffuser. This is a bowl-shaped attachment with protruding prongs, and is designed to offer a gentle, wide flow of air to set curls in place.
While many hair dryers come with a diffuser, some are more specialized than others. Shark makes a diffuser with extendable prongs, for example, while Dyson makes one where the prongs can be removed to leave a dome, to shape and define curls.
Is a hair dryer harmful to hair?
Yes – regularly using a hair dryer on your hair can cause damage to the surface. However, it's not quite as clear-cut as you might assume. A 2011 study found that using a hair dryer on hair only damaged the outer cuticle layer of hair, and didn't reach the inner cortex layer. It also found that air drying in fact caused damage to the cell membrane complex (the glue that hold your hair cells together), while blow drying did not, and came to the ultimate conclusion that blow drying your hair at a distance of 15cm and keeping the dryer moving led to less damage than leaving it to air dry naturally.
Temperature matters, too. A 1984 study found that applying heat of more than 140C (284F) caused "profound and irreversible" changed to the structure of the hair, and suggested a drying temperature of 60C (140F) was optimal.
There are precautions you can take to lessen heat damage. It's best not to start with sopping wet hair; ideally you'd get it 70-80% dry before going in with heat – for best results, you should squeeze it with a microfiber towel. Apply a heat protector spray, stick to a lower heat level and keep the dryer moving. Some dryers now offer a temperature cycling mode, which shifts between hot and cool, to lessen heat damage.
What does wattage mean for hair dryers?
The wattage is a rough indicator of how much power a hair dryer has, which can translate to it being capable of hotter temperatures and faster airspeeds, which in turn can mean quicker drying. Anything over 1500W is acceptable, and if you want something really efficient, 1800W is ideal. It's not always a case of the higher the number, the better the dryer, though: other design elements will also play into how effective it is, and different hair types might suit cooler or lower speeds (too much heat will damage hair, in any case).

We also monitored the sound level, and factored in how comfortable and balanced they were to use. argos_summary: The Dreame AirStyle Pro is a promising multi-styler that competes with the Dyson Airwrap, featuring a stylish design and a variety of attachments, including auto-wrap curl barrels. However, it falls short due to its insufficient heat settings, which struggle to dry hair effectively, and attachments that do not secure firmly, leading to potential mishaps during styling. While it offers a premium feel and comfort, the performance issues make it hard to recommend over similarly priced alternatives like the Shark FlexStyle.
